meta.description: Full AKT question bank: 200 Clinical Medicine questions (akt-001 to akt-200) + 75 EBP/PCOM questions (ebp-001 to pcom-075)

questions.stem: Absolute risk reduction (ARR) is best defined as:
options: Relative reduction in risk between two groups
Difference in outcome rates between intervention and control groups
Likelihood of benefit in an individual patient
Ratio of treated to untreated outcomes
questions.explanation: Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) is the absolute difference in outcome rates between the intervention and control groups. It is calculated as: ARR = control event rate - treatment event rate. This is different from relative risk reduction, which expresses the reduction as a percentage of the baseline risk.
keyPoints: ARR = control event rate - treatment event rate
ARR is an absolute measure, not a ratio
ARR is used to calculate NNT (Number Needed to Treat)
ARR provides more clinically meaningful information than relative measures

questions.stem: A treatment reduces stroke risk from 10% to 7%. What is the NNT?
questions.explanation: NNT (Number Needed to Treat) = 1 / ARR. ARR = 10% - 7% = 3% (0.03). Therefore, NNT = 1 / 0.03 = 33.33, which rounds to 33. This means you need to treat 33 people to prevent one stroke.
keyPoints: Lower NNT indicates more effective treatment

questions.explanation: A wide confidence interval indicates greater uncertainty in the estimate. This can result from small sample size, high variability in the data, or both. Narrow confidence intervals indicate more precise estimates, typically from larger sample sizes.
keyPoints: CI width depends on sample size and variability
95% CI means 95% chance the true value lies within the interval

options: Ability to correctly identify those without disease
Probability disease is present if test positive
Ability to correctly identify those with disease
questions.explanation: Sensitivity (true positive rate) measures the ability of a test to correctly identify those WITH the disease. It is calculated as: True Positives / (True Positives + False Negatives). A highly sensitive test has few false negatives.
keyPoints: High sensitivity = good at ruling OUT disease (SnNout)
Sensitivity is independent of disease prevalence
Used for screening tests where missing disease is dangerous

questions.stem: A highly sensitive test is best used to:
questions.explanation: A highly sensitive test is best used to rule out disease (SnNout: Sensitive test, Negative result rules OUT disease). If a sensitive test is negative, the disease is unlikely to be present. Specific tests are used to rule in disease (SpPin: Specific test, Positive result rules IN disease).
keyPoints: High sensitivity = good for ruling OUT disease
SnNout: Sensitive test, Negative = rules OUT
SpPin: Specific test, Positive = rules IN

questions.explanation: Specificity measures the ability to correctly identify those WITHOUT disease (true negatives). It is calculated as: True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Positives). A highly specific test has few false positives.
keyPoints: High specificity = good at ruling IN disease (SpPin)
Specificity is independent of disease prevalence

questions.stem: Positive predictive value (PPV) depends most on:
questions.explanation: Positive Predictive Value (PPV) depends most on the prevalence of disease in the population being tested. PPV = (Sensitivity × Prevalence) / [(Sensitivity × Prevalence) + (1 - Specificity) × (1 - Prevalence)]. In low prevalence populations, even highly specific tests can have low PPV due to many false positives.
keyPoints: PPV depends on prevalence, sensitivity, and specificity
Low prevalence = lower PPV even with good test
PPV answers: 'If test positive, what's the chance they have disease?'

questions.stem: Likelihood ratios are useful because they:
questions.explanation: Likelihood ratios combine sensitivity and specificity into a single measure that can be used to update pre-test probability. Positive LR = Sensitivity / (1 - Specificity). Negative LR = (1 - Sensitivity) / Specificity. They are useful because they don't depend on prevalence and can be applied to any patient.
keyPoints: Can be used with Bayes' theorem to update probability

questions.explanation: Type I error (alpha error) is a false positive - rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true. This is the risk of concluding there is an effect when there isn't one. The p-value represents the probability of a Type I error.
keyPoints: Rejecting null hypothesis when it's true

options: Detecting a difference when none exists
questions.explanation: Type II error (beta error) is a false negative - failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is actually false. This means missing a real difference that exists. Power = 1 - beta, so increasing power reduces Type II error risk.
keyPoints: Failing to detect a real difference

options: There is a 95% chance the result is correct
questions.explanation: A p-value <0.05 means that if the null hypothesis were true, there is less than a 5% chance of observing results this extreme. It suggests the null hypothesis is unlikely, but does NOT mean the result is clinically important, correct, or that the study is unbiased.
keyPoints: p < 0.05 = less than 5% chance of results if null hypothesis true
Does NOT mean result is clinically important
Does NOT mean 95% chance result is correct

questions.explanation: Mortality is a patient-centred outcome - it directly matters to patients. Cholesterol reduction, HbA1c change, and biomarker improvement are surrogate endpoints - they may predict patient outcomes but don't directly measure what matters to patients (death, quality of life, symptoms).
keyPoints: Patient-centred outcomes: mortality, quality of life, symptoms
Surrogate endpoints may not reflect patient benefit
Always prefer patient-centred outcomes when available

questions.stem: Which study design best establishes causality?
questions.explanation: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs) best establish causality because randomisation eliminates confounding and selection bias. By randomly assigning participants to groups, known and unknown confounders are distributed equally, allowing causal inference.

questions.stem: Case–control studies are most useful for:
questions.explanation: Case-control studies are most useful for rare diseases because they start with cases (people with disease) and controls (people without), making them efficient for rare outcomes. They cannot measure incidence or prevalence directly, but can calculate odds ratios.
keyPoints: Start with outcome, look back at exposure

questions.stem: Which bias occurs when participants differ systematically between groups?
questions.explanation: Selection bias occurs when participants differ systematically between groups due to how they were selected. This can happen in non-randomised studies where groups differ in ways that affect the outcome, not just the intervention.
keyPoints: Selection bias = systematic differences in group selection

questions.explanation: Intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis preserves randomisation by analysing all participants in the groups they were originally assigned to, regardless of adherence or crossover. This maintains the benefits of randomisation and provides a more realistic estimate of effectiveness in real-world practice.
keyPoints: Prevents bias from excluding non-adherent patients

questions.stem: A systematic review differs from a narrative review because it:
questions.explanation: A systematic review uses explicit, reproducible methodology to identify, select, and critically appraise all relevant studies. Narrative reviews are opinion-based summaries without systematic methodology. Systematic reviews may or may not include meta-analysis.

Heterogeneity in meta-analysis refers to variation between study results. High heterogeneity suggests studies may be measuring different things or have different populations/interventions. It's assessed using I² statistic or Cochran's Q test.
keyPoints: High heterogeneity = studies may be different
High heterogeneity reduces confidence in pooled results

questions.explanation: Funnel plot asymmetry suggests publication bias - small negative studies may be missing from the literature. In a symmetric funnel plot, smaller studies show more scatter around the true effect. Asymmetry suggests missing studies, often those with negative results.
keyPoints: Funnel plot asymmetry = possible publication bias

questions.explanation: Effective treatment available is an essential screening principle. Screening should only be done if there's an effective treatment for the condition when detected early. Other principles include: important condition, suitable test, acceptable test, natural history understood, and cost-effective.
keyPoints: Other principles: important condition, suitable test, cost-effective

options: Diagnosing disease that would not cause harm
questions.explanation: Overdiagnosis is diagnosing disease that would never have caused symptoms or harm during the person's lifetime. This is different from false positives (test incorrectly positive) - overdiagnosis means the disease exists but wouldn't have mattered. Common with screening.
keyPoints: Overdiagnosis = disease exists but wouldn't cause harm
Leads to unnecessary treatment and anxiety

options: Increase survival time without changing outcome
questions.explanation: Lead-time bias makes screening appear to improve survival by detecting disease earlier, but the patient doesn't live longer - they just know about the disease longer. The time from diagnosis to death is the same, but diagnosis happens earlier, making survival time appear longer.
keyPoints: Lead-time bias = earlier diagnosis, not longer life
Survival time appears longer but outcome unchanged
Only mortality reduction proves screening benefit

questions.explanation: Number Needed to Harm (NNH) = 1 / Absolute Risk Increase (ARI). ARI = harm rate in treatment group - harm rate in control group. NNH tells you how many people need to be treated for one person to experience harm.
keyPoints: ARI = treatment harm rate - control harm rate
Used to balance benefits vs harms

questions.stem: A surrogate endpoint is problematic because it:
questions.explanation: Surrogate endpoints (like cholesterol, blood pressure) may not reflect actual patient benefit (like mortality, quality of life). A treatment might improve a surrogate but not improve patient outcomes, or vice versa. Always prefer patient-centred outcomes when available.
keyPoints: Surrogate endpoints may not reflect patient benefit

questions.stem: Pragmatic trials differ from explanatory trials because they:
questions.explanation: Pragmatic trials test interventions in real-world conditions with typical patients, settings, and practices. Explanatory trials test under ideal conditions with strict criteria. Pragmatic trials better predict real-world effectiveness.
keyPoints: Pragmatic trials more applicable to practice

options: A third factor affects both exposure and outcome
questions.explanation: Confounding occurs when a third factor (confounder) is associated with both the exposure and outcome, creating a spurious association. Randomisation, matching, or statistical adjustment (multivariable analysis) can control for confounding.
keyPoints: Confounder = third factor affecting both exposure and outcome
Can adjust statistically in observational studies

questions.explanation: External validity (generalizability) is the extent to which study results can be applied to other populations, settings, or times. Internal validity is whether the study correctly measured what it intended. High internal validity doesn't guarantee external validity.
keyPoints: Can results apply to other populations/settings?
Pragmatic trials have higher external validity

questions.explanation: Statistical power (ability to detect a real effect) is increased by larger sample size, larger effect size, higher significance level (alpha), and lower variability. Power = 1 - Type II error rate. Most studies aim for 80% power.
keyPoints: Power increased by: larger sample, larger effect, lower variability
Low power = high risk of missing real effects

questions.stem: Relative risk reduction can be misleading because it:
questions.explanation: Relative risk reduction (RRR) can be misleading because it doesn't account for baseline risk. A 50% RRR sounds impressive, but if baseline risk is 2%, the absolute reduction is only 1%. Always consider absolute risk reduction (ARR) and NNT for clinical meaning.
keyPoints: RRR doesn't account for baseline risk

questions.stem: Best way to communicate risk to patients:
questions.explanation: Natural frequencies (e.g., '1 in 100 people') are better understood than percentages or relative risks. They provide context and are easier to visualize. Avoid medical jargon and always explain graphs.

Bayesian reasoning updates probability (pre-test probability) with new evidence (test results) to get post-test probability. It combines prior knowledge with new information, which is how clinicians actually think.
keyPoints: Pre-test probability + test result = post-test probability

questions.stem: Which factor most increases false positives?
questions.explanation: Low specificity most increases false positives. Specificity = TN / (TN + FP), so low specificity means more false positives. High prevalence increases false positives in absolute numbers but not proportionally. Sensitivity affects false negatives, not false positives.
keyPoints: Specificity = ability to correctly identify those without disease
High prevalence increases absolute false positives

questions.stem: Minimal clinically important difference (MCID) refers to:
options: Smallest change patients perceive as beneficial
questions.explanation: Minimal Clinically Important Difference (MCID) is the smallest change in an outcome that patients perceive as meaningful or beneficial. This is different from statistical significance - a change can be statistically significant but not clinically meaningful.
keyPoints: MCID = smallest meaningful change to patients

questions.stem: A negative likelihood ratio close to zero means:
questions.explanation: A negative likelihood ratio (LR-) close to zero means the test rules out disease very well. LR- = (1 - Sensitivity) / Specificity. When LR- is very low (e.g., <0.1), a negative test strongly rules out disease.
keyPoints: LR- close to zero = excellent at ruling out
SnNout: Sensitive test, Negative = rules OUT

questions.explanation: Cost-effectiveness is usually expressed as ICER (Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio) = (Cost of intervention - Cost of control) / (Effect of intervention - Effect of control). NICE uses ICER in £/QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year).

questions.stem: NICE uses which threshold for cost-effectiveness?
questions.explanation: NICE typically uses a threshold range of £20,000-30,000 per QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year) for cost-effectiveness. Interventions below this are usually recommended, above this may require special consideration.
keyPoints: Above threshold = may need special consideration
QALY combines quality and length of life

questions.explanation: QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year) combines quality of life and length of life into a single measure. 1 QALY = 1 year of perfect health. Years in poor health are weighted down (e.g., 0.5 QALY for a year at 50% quality of life).
keyPoints: Combines quality and length of life

questions.explanation: A cluster randomised trial randomises groups (clusters) such as practices, hospitals, or communities, rather than individuals. This is used when the intervention is delivered at the group level or to avoid contamination between groups.
keyPoints: Cluster RCT = randomises groups, not individuals
Requires larger sample size due to clustering

questions.explanation: Regression to the mean is the statistical phenomenon where extreme measurements tend to move toward the average on remeasurement. This can make interventions appear effective when improvement is just natural fluctuation. Control groups help account for this.
keyPoints: Regression to mean = extreme values move toward average
Can make interventions appear effective falsely

questions.stem: The main purpose of critical appraisal is to:
questions.explanation: Critical appraisal identifies bias, assesses study quality, and determines applicability to your patients. It helps you decide whether study results are valid, important, and applicable to your clinical practice.
keyPoints: Critical appraisal = assess validity, importance, applicability
Determine if results apply to your patients

questions.stem: The GP partnership model is best described as:
questions.explanation: GP partners are independent contractors to the NHS, not employees. They run their own businesses, are responsible for premises and staff, and receive income from practice profits. This is different from salaried GPs who are employees.
keyPoints: GP partners = independent contractors to NHS
Run own business, responsible for premises/staff

questions.stem: Core GP contract type in England:
questions.explanation: GMS (General Medical Services) is the core national contract type in England. It's the standard contract that most practices use. PMS (Personal Medical Services) and APMS (Alternative Provider Medical Services) are less common alternatives.

questions.stem: Practice income is primarily derived from:
questions.explanation: Practice income comes primarily from the Global Sum (core funding based on list size and demographics) plus enhanced services (optional commissioned services). QOF provides additional performance-related payments but is not the primary income source.
keyPoints: Primary income = Global Sum + Enhanced Services
Global Sum = core funding based on list size

questions.explanation: QOF (Quality and Outcomes Framework) aims to improve quality of care by incentivising evidence-based practice through performance-related payments. It rewards practices for meeting quality indicators in areas like chronic disease management.
keyPoints: Aims to improve quality of care

questions.explanation: Enhanced services are optional services that practices can choose to provide, commissioned by CCGs/ICBs. Examples include minor surgery, vaccinations, and extended hours. They provide additional income but are not mandatory.
keyPoints: Examples: minor surgery, vaccinations, extended hours

questions.explanation: Total triage aims to match demand to capacity safely by ensuring all patient requests are assessed and directed to the most appropriate service (GP, nurse, pharmacist, self-care). It improves access and efficiency, not reduces it.
keyPoints: Total triage = match demand to capacity safely
All requests assessed and directed appropriately

questions.explanation: Online consultation risks include missed red flags because you can't see the patient, assess non-verbal cues, or examine them. Good documentation is important but doesn't eliminate the risk. Workload may not always reduce.
keyPoints: Online consultation = risk of missed red flags

questions.explanation: Safe triage documentation must include clinical reasoning (what you considered), red flags excluded, safety-netting (when to return), and follow-up plan. Just symptoms or template text alone is insufficient and medicolegally risky.
keyPoints: Must document: differentials considered, red flags excluded

questions.explanation: Non-NHS work (medical reports, insurance forms, private consultations) can be charged for. These are outside routine NHS contractual duties. Practices can set appropriate fees (check current BMA/RCGP guidance for rates).
keyPoints: Non-NHS work = can charge appropriate fees
Check BMA/RCGP for current fee guidance

questions.explanation: DVLA advice must be documented clearly in the patient's notes. This is medicolegally essential. Verbal advice alone is insufficient. Patients have a legal duty to inform DVLA, but GPs should document advice given.
keyPoints: DVLA advice = must be documented clearly
Patient has legal duty to inform DVLA

questions.stem: A significant event analysis should focus on:
questions.explanation: Significant Event Analysis (SEA) should focus on learning and system improvement, not blame or punishment. It's a quality improvement tool to understand what happened and prevent recurrence, not to assign fault.
keyPoints: SEA = focus on learning and system improvement

questions.explanation: Complaints handling best practice includes open, reflective responses that acknowledge concerns, investigate thoroughly, and learn from the situation. Defensive responses, ignoring complaints, or legal language only worsen situations.
keyPoints: Avoid defensive or legal language only

questions.explanation: CQC (Care Quality Commission) domains are: Safe, Effective, Caring, Responsive, and Well-led. 'Profitable' is not a CQC domain. CQC assesses quality of care, not financial performance.
keyPoints: CQC domains: Safe, Effective, Caring, Responsive, Well-led

questions.explanation: Safeguarding concerns override patient confidentiality when there is a risk of serious harm to the patient or others (especially children or vulnerable adults). This is a legal and ethical duty, even without patient consent.
keyPoints: Risk of serious harm = must share information
Especially for children and vulnerable adults

questions.stem: Information governance requires data to be:
questions.explanation: Information governance requires patient data to be stored securely, with appropriate access controls, encryption, and compliance with GDPR/Data Protection Act. Data should only be shared when appropriate and with proper safeguards.

Medical indemnity schemes cover civil negligence claims (clinical negligence). They do NOT cover criminal acts, fraud, or GMC sanctions. Coverage is for clinical work-related claims, not all errors or misconduct.
keyPoints: Does NOT cover: criminal acts, fraud, GMC sanctions

questions.explanation: Appraisal primarily supports reflection and professional development. While it's required for revalidation, its main purpose is to help doctors reflect on their practice, identify learning needs, and plan development. It's not just paperwork.

Revalidation occurs every 5 years. GPs must demonstrate they remain fit to practise through annual appraisals and a revalidation recommendation every 5 years. This is a GMC requirement for maintaining a licence to practise.

A good GP note demonstrates clinical reasoning - showing what you considered, why you made decisions, what red flags you excluded, and your safety-netting. Volume, speed, or templates alone don't make good notes - reasoning does.
keyPoints: Show: differentials considered, red flags excluded, safety-netting

questions.explanation: AI use in consultations requires clinician oversight - the clinician remains responsible and must review all AI output. AI supports, not replaces, clinical judgement. Patient consent and disclosure are typically required, and output must be reviewed.

questions.stem: Data entered into AI tools must be:
questions.explanation: Data entered into AI tools must be compliant with data protection (GDPR/Data Protection Act). Patient-identifiable data should only be entered into approved, secure systems with appropriate data processing agreements. Never use public AI tools for patient data.
keyPoints: AI data = must comply with data protection
Never use public AI tools for patient data

questions.explanation: Partnership income depends on practice profit - partners share in practice profits (or losses). This is different from salaried GPs who receive a fixed salary. Income varies based on practice performance, expenses, and profit distribution.
keyPoints: Different from salaried GP fixed salary

questions.explanation: Salaried GPs are employees of the practice, not contractors or partners. They receive a fixed salary, have no business risk, and don't control practice finances. They can do private work if their contract allows.
keyPoints: Can do private work if contract allows

questions.explanation: Locum GPs must ensure adequate personal indemnity. Employers may provide some cover, but locums are responsible for ensuring they have appropriate indemnity for their work. They also need GMC registration and should engage in appraisal.
keyPoints: Locums = must have adequate personal indemnity

questions.stem: Workforce supervision of trainees is provided by:
questions.explanation: Workforce supervision of GP trainees is provided by the Educational Supervisor (ES). The ES is responsible for overall training, portfolio review, and ARCP preparation. Clinical Supervisors provide day-to-day supervision in placements.
keyPoints: Responsible for portfolio review and ARCP

questions.explanation: Raising concerns (whistleblowing) guidance encourages speaking up appropriately through proper channels (line manager, freedom to speak up guardian, GMC if necessary). External media or social media should be last resort after internal channels exhausted.
keyPoints: Protected by law when done appropriately

questions.explanation: Professional boundaries require clear limits and transparency. GPs should have clear boundaries around gifts (small tokens may be acceptable, large gifts are not), treating family (emergency only), and social media (maintain professional boundaries).
keyPoints: Professional boundaries = clear limits and transparency
Small gifts may be acceptable, large gifts not

questions.explanation: Medical reports should be factual and evidence-based, sticking to what's in the notes and what you've observed. Avoid speculation or opinion beyond what the evidence supports. Reports should be reviewed by the GP, not delegated without oversight.

questions.stem: Most common medicolegal risk in general practice:
questions.explanation: Communication failure is the most common medicolegal risk in general practice. Most complaints and claims arise from breakdowns in communication - not explaining things clearly, poor safety-netting, or miscommunication with patients or colleagues.

questions.stem: Fitness to drive responsibility lies with:
questions.explanation: Fitness to drive responsibility lies with the patient - they have a legal duty to inform DVLA of medical conditions affecting driving. GPs should advise patients of this duty and document advice given, but the legal responsibility is the patient's.
keyPoints: Fitness to drive = patient's legal responsibility
GP can inform DVLA if patient doesn't (in certain circumstances)

questions.explanation: Advance care planning should reflect patient values, preferences, and wishes. It should involve the patient (and family if patient wishes) and be documented clearly. It's not clinician-led only, secret, or something to delay.
keyPoints: Advance care planning = reflect patient values
Involve patient and family (if patient wishes)
Should be done early, not delayed

questions.explanation: DNACPR discussions should be sensitive and documented clearly. They should involve the patient (if they have capacity) or be in their best interests, and should happen early when appropriate, not be avoided or delayed until crisis.
keyPoints: Involve patient if they have capacity

questions.explanation: Health inequalities work includes advocacy and access improvement - addressing social determinants of health, ensuring equitable access to services, and advocating for patients who face barriers. GPs have a role in addressing health inequalities.
keyPoints: Health inequalities = advocacy and access improvement

questions.stem: Effective leadership in primary care requires:
questions.explanation: Effective leadership in primary care requires emotional intelligence - understanding and managing emotions, building relationships, and working collaboratively. Authority alone, speed, or hierarchy are insufficient. Leadership is about influence, not just position.
keyPoints: Essential for GP partners and team leaders

questions.stem: Most important exam strategy for PCOM questions:
questions.explanation: The most important exam strategy for PCOM questions is selecting the safest, patient-centred answer. This is usually the option that prioritises patient safety, follows guidelines, and demonstrates good clinical governance. It's not about cost or defensive medicine.
keyPoints: Not about cost or being defensive

questions.stem: A 49-year-old man has clinic BP readings of 146/92 and 150/94 mmHg. He has no symptoms and no evidence of target organ damage. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: NICE recommends that when clinic BP ≥140/90 mmHg you should offer ABPM (or home BP monitoring) to confirm diagnosis rather than treating based on clinic reading alone (except in very high readings or end-organ damage). ABPM diagnostic threshold daytime average ≥135/85 mmHg.
keyPoints: ABPM is required to confirm hypertension diagnosis when clinic BP ≥140/90
Avoid treating on clinic readings alone unless very high or end-organ damage present

questions.stem: Which ABPM daytime average confirms a diagnosis of hypertension?
questions.explanation: NICE guidelines state that ABPM daytime average ≥135/85 mmHg confirms hypertension. This is lower than clinic BP threshold (≥140/90) because ABPM eliminates white coat hypertension.
keyPoints: Lower than clinic threshold due to white coat effect

questions.stem: A 56-year-old man has a QRISK3 score of 12%. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation: NICE recommends atorvastatin 20mg for primary prevention when QRISK3 ≥10%. QRISK3 of 12% exceeds the threshold, so statin therapy is indicated. Atorvastatin 20mg is the standard starting dose for primary prevention.
keyPoints: QRISK3 ≥10% = consider statin for primary prevention
Higher doses (80mg) reserved for secondary prevention or very high risk
Lifestyle advice should accompany statin therapy

questions.stem: A 72-year-old woman with AF has hypertension and diabetes. CHA₂DS₂-VASc score is 4. What is the correct management?
options: Refer to cardiology before any treatment
questions.explanation: CHA₂DS₂-VASc score ≥2 in women (or ≥1 in men) indicates high stroke risk requiring anticoagulation. DOACs (apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban, dabigatran) are preferred over warfarin unless contraindicated. Aspirin is no longer recommended for stroke prevention in AF.
keyPoints: Aspirin not recommended for AF stroke prevention
Check HAS-BLED for bleeding risk before starting

questions.stem: Which investigation is most appropriate initial test for suspected heart failure in primary care?
questions.explanation: NICE recommends BNP or NT-proBNP as the initial investigation for suspected heart failure in primary care. If elevated, this triggers referral for echocardiogram. ECG and CXR may be done but BNP is the key screening test.
keyPoints: BNP/NT-proBNP = initial test for suspected heart failure
BNP <100 pg/mL (or NT-proBNP <400 pg/mL) makes heart failure unlikely
Echo confirms diagnosis and assesses function

questions.stem: Which finding supports a diagnosis of asthma?
questions.explanation: Peak flow variability >20% (or >400ml in FEV1) supports asthma diagnosis. Fixed airflow obstruction and FEV1/FVC <0.7 post-bronchodilator suggest COPD. Reduced DLCO suggests parenchymal disease. Normal spirometry doesn't rule out asthma but doesn't support it.
keyPoints: Reversible airflow obstruction is key feature
Spirometry with reversibility testing is diagnostic

questions.stem: A 67-year-old man with COPD has FEV1 48% predicted and two exacerbations in the past year. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: NICE recommends LABA/LAMA combination for patients with FEV1 <50% predicted and ≥2 exacerbations per year. This is step 3 in COPD management. SABA alone is insufficient. Long-term oral steroids should be avoided due to side effects. Antibiotic prophylaxis is considered but not first-line.

questions.stem: Which scoring system is commonly used in primary care to assess pneumonia severity?
questions.explanation: CURB-65 is the standard scoring system for assessing pneumonia severity in primary care. It helps determine whether patients can be managed at home (0-1), need hospital admission (2), or require ICU (3-5). Wells score is for PE, CHA₂DS₂-VASc for AF stroke risk, NEWS2 for general deterioration, QRISK3 for CVD risk.

questions.stem: Which HbA1c value confirms a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes (not pregnant)?
questions.explanation: WHO and NICE define diabetes as HbA1c ≥48 mmol/mol (6.5%). 42-47 mmol/mol is prediabetes. ≥48 mmol/mol on two separate occasions (or one reading with symptoms) confirms diabetes.
keyPoints: Two readings or one with symptoms confirms diagnosis

questions.stem: What is the first-line pharmacological treatment for most people with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes?
questions.explanation: NICE recommends metformin as first-line pharmacological treatment for type 2 diabetes, alongside lifestyle advice. It's well-tolerated, reduces cardiovascular risk, and doesn't cause weight gain or hypoglycaemia. Insulin is reserved for severe hyperglycaemia or when oral agents fail.

questions.stem: A patient with insulin-treated diabetes has recurrent hypoglycaemia. What advice regarding driving is correct?
questions.explanation: Patients with insulin-treated diabetes experiencing recurrent hypoglycaemia must inform DVLA. They should not drive until hypoglycaemia is controlled. DVLA guidance requires reporting of any condition that may affect driving safety.

questions.stem: A 25-year-old non-pregnant woman presents with uncomplicated cystitis. First-line antibiotic?
questions.explanation: NICE recommends nitrofurantoin as first-line for uncomplicated UTI in non-pregnant women. It has good urinary concentration, low resistance rates, and is safe in pregnancy. Trimethoprim is alternative first-line. Ciprofloxacin should be reserved due to resistance concerns.

questions.stem: Which feature suggests upper UTI requiring urgent assessment?
questions.explanation: Flank pain and fever suggest pyelonephritis (upper UTI) requiring urgent assessment and likely hospital admission. Lower UTI symptoms (dysuria, frequency, suprapubic pain) can be managed in primary care. Cloudy urine is non-specific.
keyPoints: Lower UTI = dysuria, frequency, suprapubic pain

questions.stem: A 62-year-old man has iron deficiency anaemia. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: NICE recommends 2-week wait referral for suspected cancer in men >60 with iron deficiency anaemia (unless obvious cause). This is to exclude GI malignancy. Oral iron should be started but investigation is mandatory. B12/folate should also be checked.

questions.stem: Unintentional weight loss with which feature most strongly suggests malignancy?
questions.explanation: Unintentional weight loss with iron deficiency anaemia strongly suggests GI malignancy and requires urgent investigation. Recent bereavement and depression are common causes but IDA adds red flag. Smoking alone is a risk factor but not diagnostic.
keyPoints: Weight loss + IDA = red flag for malignancy

questions.explanation: Suicidal ideation indicates severe depression and requires urgent mental health assessment. Poor sleep, low mood, reduced appetite, and fatigue are common symptoms but don't necessarily indicate severity. Risk assessment is crucial.

Sertraline is commonly recommended as first-line SSRI due to good efficacy, tolerability, and safety profile. It's particularly useful in cardiac patients. Fluoxetine is also first-line. Paroxetine has more withdrawal effects. Venlafaxine is SNRI, not SSRI.

questions.stem: Which is required for a patient to have capacity?
options: Ability to retain, weigh, and communicate decision
questions.explanation: Mental Capacity Act 2005 defines capacity as ability to: understand information, retain it, weigh it up, and communicate decision. Agreement with doctor, age, or family approval are not required. Capacity is decision-specific and can fluctuate.

questions.stem: Which statement about consent is correct?
options: Consent can be withdrawn at any time
questions.explanation: Consent can be withdrawn at any time, even during a procedure. Verbal consent is valid for many procedures. Written consent is required for major procedures. Capacity is not permanent and can fluctuate. Implied consent is valid for routine examinations.
keyPoints: Consent can be withdrawn at any time

options: Risk of serious harm to others
questions.explanation: GMC guidance allows disclosure without consent when there is risk of serious harm to others (e.g., violent crime, serious communicable disease). This is a limited exception. Employer, media, insurance, and family requests do not override confidentiality without patient consent.
keyPoints: Risk of serious harm = can override confidentiality

questions.stem: Which symptom suggests cauda equina syndrome?
questions.explanation: Saddle anaesthesia (numbness in perineum/saddle area) is a red flag for cauda equina syndrome requiring urgent neurosurgical referral. Other red flags include bilateral sciatica, bladder/bowel dysfunction, and lower limb weakness.
keyPoints: Saddle anaesthesia = cauda equina red flag
Other red flags: bilateral sciatica, bladder/bowel dysfunction

questions.explanation: Headache with papilloedema suggests raised intracranial pressure and requires urgent referral. This could indicate brain tumour, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, or other serious pathology. Tension-type, migraine, and cluster headaches are usually managed in primary care.
keyPoints: Other red flags: thunderclap, focal neurology, confusion

questions.stem: After a single unprovoked seizure, what advice is correct?
questions.explanation: After a single unprovoked seizure, patients must inform DVLA and stop driving. DVLA will typically require 6-12 months seizure-free before license return. Driving with epilepsy/seizures is illegal and dangerous.
keyPoints: Illegal to drive with active seizures

questions.stem: If baseline risk is 10% and relative risk reduction is 25%, what is the NNT?
questions.explanation: NNT = 1 / ARR. Baseline risk 10%, RRR 25% means absolute risk reduction = 10% × 0.25 = 2.5%. NNT = 1 / 0.025 = 40. This means 40 people need treatment for 1 to benefit.

A wide confidence interval indicates greater uncertainty about the true effect. Narrow intervals indicate high precision. Larger sample sizes typically produce narrower (more precise) intervals. Bias is separate from precision.
keyPoints: CI width reflects precision, not bias

questions.explanation: ACE inhibitors like ramipril commonly cause hyperkalaemia by reducing aldosterone production, which normally promotes potassium excretion. This is particularly important in patients with CKD or on potassium-sparing diuretics. Amlodipine (calcium channel blocker), metformin, atorvastatin, and paracetamol do not typically cause hyperkalaemia.

questions.stem: Which eGFR corresponds to CKD stage 3a?
questions.explanation: CKD stage 3a is defined as eGFR 45-59 ml/min/1.73m² with evidence of kidney damage. Stage 1: ≥90, Stage 2: 60-89, Stage 3a: 45-59, Stage 3b: 30-44, Stage 4: 15-29, Stage 5: <15.

questions.stem: Which patient is at highest risk from NSAIDs?
questions.explanation: Patients with CKD stage 3 are at highest risk from NSAIDs due to risk of AKI, fluid retention, and hyperkalaemia. NSAIDs reduce renal blood flow via prostaglandin inhibition. Other high-risk groups include heart failure, peptic ulcer disease, and elderly patients.
keyPoints: Risk of AKI and fluid retention
Avoid in heart failure, peptic ulcer

questions.stem: Which anticoagulant requires routine INR monitoring?
questions.explanation: Warfarin requires routine INR monitoring to maintain therapeutic range (typically 2-3 for most indications). DOACs (apixaban, rivaroxaban, dabigatran, edoxaban) do not require routine monitoring, which is one of their advantages.
keyPoints: DOACs do not require routine monitoring

questions.stem: Which is a contraindication to combined oral contraceptive pill?
questions.explanation: Migraine with aura is an absolute contraindication to combined oral contraceptive due to increased stroke risk. Migraine without aura is acceptable. Age 32 and BMI 28 are not contraindications. Smoking over 35 is a contraindication, but under 35 is acceptable.
keyPoints: Migraine with aura = absolute contraindication to COCP

questions.stem: Up to how many days after intercourse can a copper IUD be used?
questions.explanation: Copper IUD can be used as emergency contraception up to 5 days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse. It is the most effective form of emergency contraception and can be left in place for ongoing contraception.
keyPoints: Copper IUD = up to 5 days post-coital

questions.stem: Which condition requires immediate referral in pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Reduced fetal movements require immediate assessment in pregnancy as it may indicate fetal compromise. Nausea, heartburn, back pain, and constipation are common pregnancy symptoms that can usually be managed in primary care.

questions.stem: Which is a safeguarding red flag?
questions.explanation: Inconsistent injury history is a red flag for non-accidental injury and requires safeguarding referral. Missed immunisation, viral illness, and occasional school absence are not necessarily concerning. Normal development is reassuring.

questions.stem: A febrile child with non-blanching rash should:
questions.explanation: A febrile child with non-blanching rash requires urgent assessment as it may indicate meningococcal disease or other serious infection. This is a red flag requiring immediate medical attention.

Frailty is characterised by weight loss, slow gait, weakness, and reduced activity. Hypertension, diabetes, and osteoarthritis alone do not define frailty. Polypharmacy may be associated but is not diagnostic.
keyPoints: Frailty = weight loss + slow gait + weakness

questions.stem: Which medication increases falls risk most?
questions.explanation: Benzodiazepines significantly increase falls risk due to sedation, impaired balance, and cognitive effects. ACE inhibitors may cause postural hypotension. Paracetamol, statins, and metformin do not typically increase falls risk.

questions.stem: Which feature distinguishes delirium from dementia?
questions.explanation: Fluctuating consciousness and acute onset distinguish delirium from dementia. Dementia has gradual onset and stable consciousness. Both can have memory loss and behavioural changes. Age is not distinguishing.

questions.stem: Which indicates last days of life?
questions.explanation: Terminal secretions (death rattle) indicate last days of life. Reduced appetite, pain, insomnia, and anxiety can occur earlier. Terminal secretions suggest hours to days remaining.

questions.stem: Which statement is correct about DNACPR?
questions.explanation: DNACPR applies only to cardiopulmonary resuscitation, not other treatments. It does not require patient consent (though discussion is good practice). It can be reviewed and is not permanent. Family signature is not required.

QOF (Quality and Outcomes Framework) incentivises evidence-based primary care quality through payment for achieving clinical and organisational targets. It does not focus on private care, hospital activity, or research.

questions.stem: Which is correct regarding private medical reports?
questions.explanation: GPs can charge a fee for private medical reports. They can refuse if inappropriate but should consider patient needs. Examination is not always required. Opinion should be based on available information.
keyPoints: Can charge fee for private reports

questions.stem: What is the first step in managing a complaint?
questions.explanation: The first step in managing a complaint is to acknowledge it promptly and investigate the facts. This shows professionalism and allows proper resolution. Defensive responses or ignoring complaints worsen situations.
Clear documentation of clinical reasoning, differential diagnoses, and safety-netting improves medicolegal defence. Minimal notes, copy-paste, and avoiding safety-netting increase risk.

questions.stem: Which is acceptable use of AI in GP practice?
options: Entering identifiable data into public AI
questions.explanation: Drafting letters or documents using AI that are then checked and edited by a clinician is acceptable. Entering identifiable data, delegating decisions, or using without disclosure is not acceptable.
keyPoints: AI can draft, clinician must check

questions.explanation: Total triage aims to match patient demand to the most appropriate skill level (GP, nurse, pharmacist, etc.), improving efficiency and access. It doesn't aim to increase GP appointments or remove staff.

questions.stem: Which is essential to document in online consultations?
questions.explanation: Differential diagnosis and safety-netting are essential to document in online consultations, just as in face-to-face consultations. This ensures continuity and patient safety.

questions.stem: Why should trainees attend practice meetings?
questions.explanation: Trainees should attend practice meetings to understand practice systems, leadership, and business aspects of general practice. This is valuable learning for future partnership or salaried roles.

questions.stem: Which skill is most important for GP partners?
questions.explanation: Conflict management is crucial for GP partners who must navigate team dynamics, patient complaints, and practice challenges. Speed, exam scores, and research are less central to partnership success.
Boundaries and debriefing are key to preventing burnout. Longer clinics, ignoring admin, and working alone increase burnout risk. Regular debriefing and work-life boundaries are protective.

questions.stem: If unsure of an answer, the best strategy is to:
options: Eliminate options and choose best fit
questions.explanation: When unsure, eliminate clearly wrong options and choose the best fit from remaining options. This improves odds. Leaving blank, panicking, or overthinking reduce performance.

questions.stem: Which finding is consistent with primary hypothyroidism?
questions.explanation: Primary hypothyroidism shows high TSH and low T4 due to thyroid failure. Pituitary responds by increasing TSH. Low TSH with low T4 suggests secondary hypothyroidism.
keyPoints: Primary hypothyroidism = high TSH, low T4

questions.stem: Subclinical hypothyroidism is most appropriately treated when:
questions.explanation: Subclinical hypothyroidism (high TSH, normal T4) is treated when TSH >10 or if symptomatic. Age 35 with TSH 12 warrants treatment. Elderly patients with mild elevation may not need treatment.

questions.stem: Most common cause of hyperthyroidism in the UK?
questions.explanation: Graves' disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism in the UK, particularly in younger women. It's an autoimmune condition causing thyroid overactivity.

questions.stem: Red flag in thyroid eye disease?
questions.explanation: Reduced visual acuity in thyroid eye disease suggests optic nerve compression and requires urgent ophthalmology referral. Lid lag, proptosis, and grittiness are common but less urgent.

questions.stem: Most common cause of mild hypercalcaemia in primary care?
questions.explanation: Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common cause of mild hypercalcaemia in primary care. Malignancy causes more severe hypercalcaemia. Always exclude malignancy first.
Adjusted calcium corrects for albumin levels, as calcium is protein-bound. Low albumin = low total calcium but normal ionised calcium. Adjusted calcium = total Ca + 0.02 × (40 - albumin).
DEXA scanning is indicated for fragility fractures, age >65, or high risk factors. 65F with fragility fracture definitely qualifies. Age 60M smoker may qualify with other risk factors.
Bisphosphonates must be taken on empty stomach with water, and patient must remain upright for 30 minutes to prevent oesophageal irritation. Calcium should be taken separately.
Standard vitamin D replacement is 20,000 IU weekly (or equivalent daily dose). This is for deficiency. Maintenance is lower. 50,000 IU daily would be excessive.
First-line for acute gout is colchicine or NSAID (if no contraindications). Allopurinol and febuxostat are for prevention, not acute attacks. Steroids are second-line.
Allopurinol should be started after the acute attack has settled (typically 2 weeks). Starting during an attack can prolong it. It's a urate-lowering therapy for prevention.
Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) features shoulder and hip girdle pain, morning stiffness, raised ESR/CRP, and age >50. Unilateral pain is less typical. Normal ESR makes PMR unlikely.
PMR is treated with prednisolone (typically 15mg daily initially). NSAIDs are insufficient. Methotrexate may be used as steroid-sparing agent. Response to steroids is diagnostic.
Visual disturbance in GCA requires urgent high-dose steroids and ophthalmology referral to prevent permanent vision loss. Other symptoms are important but less immediately urgent.
Symmetrical small joint swelling suggests rheumatoid arthritis and requires urgent rheumatology referral (within 3 weeks) to prevent joint damage. Early treatment is crucial.
Imaging for back pain is indicated when red flags are present (e.g., cauda equina, malignancy, infection). Duration, anxiety, or job type alone are not indications.
Initial sciatica management is activity modification and analgesia. MRI is not first-line. Bed rest is not recommended. Surgery is for persistent/severe cases.
Painful arc (pain between 60-120° abduction) suggests rotator cuff tendinopathy. Frozen shoulder has global restriction. OA and cervical radiculopathy have different patterns.
Tennis elbow first-line is physiotherapy and activity modification. Steroid injection is second-line. Surgery is for refractory cases. Most resolve with conservative management.
Acute angle-closure glaucoma requires same-day ophthalmology referral as it can cause permanent vision loss. Conjunctivitis, dry eye, and blepharitis can be managed in primary care.
Flashes, floaters, and visual field defect suggest retinal detachment requiring urgent ophthalmology referral. This is a vision-threatening emergency.
keyPoints: Flashes + floaters + field defect = retinal detachment

questions.explanation: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss requires urgent ENT referral (within 24-48 hours) as early treatment with steroids may improve outcomes.
Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterised by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by head movement. It's the most common cause of vertigo.
Bell's palsy should be treated with prednisolone within 72 hours of onset. Antivirals may be added but steroids are first-line. Early treatment improves outcomes.
TIA presents with transient focal neurological symptoms (weakness, speech, vision) that resolve within 24 hours. Gradual onset or non-focal symptoms are not typical.
TIA requires same-day specialist assessment (TIA clinic) for urgent investigation and secondary prevention. Delay increases stroke risk.
Bradykinesia (slowness of movement) is a core feature of Parkinson's disease, along with rigidity and rest tremor. Spasticity and UMN signs suggest other conditions.
Alzheimer's disease is the most common type of dementia, accounting for 60-70% of cases. Vascular dementia is second most common.
Essential dementia workup includes blood tests (FBC, U&E, LFTs, TFTs, B12, folate) to exclude reversible causes. MRI is not always required initially.
Polypharmacy is a major risk factor for delirium, along with age, dementia, infection, and hospitalisation. Youth, fitness, and employment are protective.
CKD should be referred when there is rapid decline in eGFR (>5 ml/min/1.73m²/year), eGFR <30, proteinuria, or other complications. Stable CKD 3a/3b may not need referral.
AKI is diagnosed by rise in creatinine ≥26 μmol/L within 48 hours or ≥1.5x baseline. eGFR <60 alone is CKD, not AKI. Proteinuria and haematuria are not diagnostic.
Painless haematuria is a red flag requiring 2-week wait referral for suspected bladder/renal cancer. LUTS, nocturia, and frequency are common but not red flags alone.
PSA screening is not routinely offered in UK but can be done after informed discussion about risks/benefits. It's not mandatory or restricted to private/age >70.
Testicular lump requires urgent ultrasound (within 2 weeks) to exclude malignancy. This is a 2-week wait referral. Do not delay or treat with antibiotics.
PDE-5 inhibitors (sildenafil, tadalafil) are first-line for erectile dysfunction. Testosterone is only if hypogonadism confirmed. Surgery is last resort.
HRT is first-line for vasomotor symptoms if suitable (no contraindications). SSRIs and gabapentin are alternatives. Lifestyle alone is often insufficient.
Postmenopausal bleeding requires urgent 2-week wait referral for suspected endometrial cancer. This is a red flag symptom not to be delayed.
Cervical screening in UK is every 3 years for ages 25-49, then every 5 years for ages 50-64. This changed from previous guidelines.
Chlamydia is the most common STI and is routinely screened in young sexually active people. Other STIs are screened based on risk factors.

questions.stem: HIV testing should be offered with:
questions.explanation: HIV testing should be offered to patients with indicator conditions (e.g., TB, lymphoma, certain infections) as per BHIVA guidelines. It should be normalised, not restricted.
Tuberculosis is a notifiable disease - all suspected and confirmed cases must be reported to Public Health England. This is a legal requirement.
MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) is a live vaccine. Tetanus, Hep B, HPV, and flu (inactivated) are not live vaccines.
Live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy, during chemotherapy, and in immunocompromised patients due to risk of vaccine-strain infection.

questions.stem: Must be disclosed for safety-critical work:
questions.explanation: Epilepsy must be disclosed for safety-critical work (e.g., driving, operating machinery) as it affects safety. Other conditions may need disclosure depending on role.
Fitness for work is assessed by occupational health, not the GP. GP provides medical information but OH makes the fitness decision based on job requirements.
Fit notes can include recommendations for workplace adjustments, phased return, or modified duties. They're not just about diagnosis or return date.
Appraisal is for professional development, reflection, and identifying learning needs. It's not for performance review, pay, or disciplinary purposes.
Revalidation is required every 5 years to maintain GMC registration. It requires annual appraisals and evidence of continuing professional development.

questions.stem: Best way to build exam stamina:
questions.explanation: Building exam stamina requires multiple full-length mock exams under timed conditions. This builds endurance and familiarises with exam format. Reading alone is insufficient.

questions.stem: Sudden severe abdominal pain in a patient with AF suggests:
questions.explanation: Sudden severe abdominal pain in a patient with AF suggests mesenteric ischaemia due to embolic occlusion. This is a surgical emergency requiring urgent assessment.
keyPoints: AF + severe abdominal pain = mesenteric ischaemia

questions.explanation: Dyspepsia with weight loss and anaemia suggests upper GI malignancy and requires urgent 2-week wait referral. This is a red flag combination.
GERD first-line management is lifestyle advice (weight loss, avoid triggers) plus alginate/antacid. PPI is second-line if symptoms persist.
IBS is characterised by abdominal pain/discomfort relieved by defecation, along with bloating and altered bowel habit. Weight loss, fever, and blood are red flags.
Coeliac disease screening uses IgA tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies. IgA deficiency requires IgG testing. Endoscopy and biopsy confirm diagnosis.
Cholestatic LFTs show raised ALP and GGT, suggesting biliary obstruction or liver disease. ALT/AST suggest hepatocellular damage.
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is managed with weight loss, lifestyle modification, and addressing metabolic risk factors. No specific medications.
Low-risk alcohol consumption is ≤14 units per week, spread across 3+ days with alcohol-free days. This applies to both men and women.
Painless jaundice suggests pancreatic or biliary malignancy and requires urgent 2-week wait referral. This is a red flag symptom.
Constipation with weight loss is a red flag requiring investigation for malignancy or other serious causes. Age, duration, and lifestyle factors are less concerning alone.
PR bleeding with anaemia suggests lower GI malignancy and requires urgent 2-week wait referral. This is a red flag combination.
Uncomplicated diverticular disease is managed with dietary advice (high fibre, fluids). Antibiotics are for diverticulitis. Surgery is for complications.
Peritonitis presents with guarding, rigidity, and rebound tenderness. This is a surgical emergency requiring urgent hospital admission.
Gallstones are the most common cause of acute pancreatitis in the UK, followed by alcohol. Other causes are less common.
Weight loss investigation starts with FBC to check for anaemia, which guides further investigation. CT, endoscopy, and tumour markers come later.
Stress incontinence (leakage on coughing/sneezing) is most common in women, particularly post-menopause and after childbirth.
Overactive bladder (OAB) first-line treatment is bladder training and lifestyle modification. Anticholinergics are second-line if needed.
Recurrent UTI prevention focuses on hydration, hygiene measures, and voiding after intercourse. Prophylactic antibiotics are second-line.
PSA can be raised by age, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), prostatitis, and prostate cancer. All factors should be considered.
Renal colic is treated with NSAIDs (e.g., diclofenac) as first-line for pain relief. Opioids are second-line. Antibiotics if infection present.
Melanoma is identified by ABCDE criteria including colour variation (multiple colours), asymmetry, border irregularity, diameter >6mm, and evolution.
Suspected melanoma requires urgent 2-week wait referral for dermatology assessment. Do not delay or attempt GP biopsy.
Mild eczema is managed with emollients as first-line. Topical steroids are added for flares. Oral steroids and antibiotics are for severe/complicated cases.
Psoriasis first-line is topical treatment with vitamin D analogue and/or topical steroid. Oral medications and biologics are for moderate-severe disease.
Moderate acne is treated with topical combination therapy (e.g., benzoyl peroxide + topical antibiotic). Oral antibiotics are for more severe cases.
Cellulitis presents with warm, tender, erythematous skin with poorly defined borders. It's a bacterial skin infection requiring antibiotics.
Shingles antivirals (aciclovir) should be started within 72 hours of rash onset for maximum benefit, especially in older adults or if ophthalmic involvement.
Varicella (chickenpox) exposure in pregnancy requires VZIG (varicella zoster immunoglobulin) if non-immune to prevent complications. Check immunity first.
Sepsis is identified by SIRS criteria including hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnoea, and altered mental state. Fever alone is not diagnostic.
Fever of unknown origin (FUO) investigation starts with thorough history and examination to guide further tests. Blood cultures, imaging, and antibiotics come after.
Anaphylaxis requires immediate IM adrenaline (epinephrine) as first-line treatment. Antihistamines and steroids are adjunctive. This is a medical emergency.
ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema requires immediate cessation of the ACE inhibitor. This is a serious adverse effect that can be life-threatening.
Poor asthma control is indicated by night-time symptoms (waking with asthma), frequent day symptoms, or frequent reliever use. Night symptoms are particularly significant.
Asthma step-up involves adding LABA (long-acting beta-agonist) to ICS if control inadequate. Increasing SABA or stopping inhalers is incorrect.
COPD antibiotics are indicated for acute exacerbations with purulent sputum, suggesting bacterial infection. Not all exacerbations need antibiotics.
COPD oxygen target is 88–92% to avoid hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis. Higher targets can be dangerous in COPD patients.
Wells score is used to assess probability of pulmonary embolism. CURB-65 is for pneumonia, CHA₂DS₂-VASc for AF, QRISK3 for CVD, FRAX for fracture.
D-dimer is used to rule out PE in low-risk patients (Wells score). If negative, PE unlikely. If positive or high risk, proceed to imaging.
Low MCV (microcytic anaemia) suggests iron deficiency. B12 and folate deficiency cause macrocytic (high MCV) anaemia.
Blood transfusion threshold is typically Hb <70 g/L (or <80 if symptomatic/cardiac disease). Higher thresholds may be appropriate in specific situations.
DVT is treated with DOACs (direct oral anticoagulants) as first-line, or warfarin if DOACs contraindicated. Aspirin is not appropriate.
DVT treatment duration is typically 3 months for provoked DVT, longer for unprovoked or recurrent. Lifelong if recurrent or high risk.
HAS-BLED score assesses bleeding risk in patients on anticoagulation. Wells is for PE, CHA₂DS₂-VASc for stroke risk, CURB-65 for pneumonia, QRISK3 for CVD.
Hyponatraemia can be caused by diuretics (especially thiazides), SIADH, heart failure, liver disease, and other conditions. Multiple causes possible.
Hyperkalaemia ECG changes include peaked T waves, widened QRS, and eventually sine wave pattern. These are medical emergencies.
Addisonian crisis (adrenal insufficiency) presents with hyperkalaemia, hyponatraemia, hypotension, and hypoglycaemia. Hyperkalaemia is a key feature.
Obesity first-line management is lifestyle intervention (diet, exercise, behaviour change). Medication and surgery are for when lifestyle fails.
Eating disorder red flags include electrolyte disturbance (especially hypokalaemia), very low BMI, bradycardia, and other medical complications.
Substance misuse is managed with brief intervention and referral to specialist services. Punishment and ignoring are not appropriate. Medication may be part of treatment.
Smoking cessation is most effective with combination of pharmacotherapy (NRT, varenicline, bupropion) and behavioural support. Advice alone is less effective.

questions.stem: At what age should a child be able to sit unsupported?
questions.explanation: Children typically sit unsupported by 6 months. 3 months is too early. 9-12 months suggests delay. 18 months is significantly delayed.

questions.stem: Which is a red flag at 18 months?
questions.explanation: Not walking by 18 months is a red flag requiring developmental assessment. Pincer grasp develops later. Social smile should be present by 6-8 weeks.
Poor eye contact is a key feature of autism spectrum disorder, along with social communication difficulties and restricted interests. Other features are less specific.
ADHD core symptoms are inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. Inattention is a key feature. Aggression, depression, and anxiety may be comorbidities.

questions.stem: Temperature ≥38°C in child under 3 months requires:
questions.explanation: Fever ≥38°C in child under 3 months requires urgent hospital assessment due to risk of serious bacterial infection. Do not manage in primary care.
DTaP/IPV/Hib (diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, polio, Hib) is given at 12 weeks as part of UK immunisation schedule. MMR is later, HPV in teenagers.

questions.stem: Which supports failure to thrive diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Failure to thrive is indicated by crossing centiles downward on growth charts. Tall parents, good appetite, and active child are reassuring. Normal weight doesn't exclude if trajectory poor.
Safeguarding documentation must be factual, contemporaneous, and detailed. Vague terms, delays, and verbal-only documentation are poor practice and medicolegally risky.
EPDS (Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale) is the screening tool for postnatal depression. GAD-7 and PHQ-9 are for general anxiety/depression.
Mastitis management involves continuing breastfeeding (important for drainage) and antibiotics if systemic symptoms or not improving. Stopping feeding worsens the condition.
Domestic abuse disclosure should be documented using patient's own words verbatim. Never ask with partner present, ignore, or promise absolute confidentiality. Don't advise confrontation.
Sexual assault requires offering referral to SARC (Sexual Assault Referral Centre). Evidence doesn't expire at 24h. Reporting to police is patient's choice. Documentation is essential.
Fluctuating capacity requires assessment at each decision point. Don't assume no capacity. Family doesn't decide. Court is last resort. Never ignore capacity issues.
Learning disability annual health checks are recommended to identify health needs early. This is part of enhanced service in primary care.

questions.stem: Mental health crisis - immediate action suicidal ideation:
questions.explanation: Suicidal ideation requires same-day crisis team assessment. This is urgent. Routine referral, reassurance, and waiting are inappropriate. Medication alone is insufficient.
keyPoints: Suicidal ideation = crisis team same day

questions.explanation: Antidepressants should be reviewed at 4-6 weeks to assess response and side effects. Earlier if concerns. 3-6 months is too late for initial review.
Benzodiazepines carry major risk of dependence and withdrawal. They should be short-term only. Hypertension, weight gain, and hyperglycaemia are not typical risks.
Antipsychotics require monitoring of weight, lipids, glucose (metabolic monitoring) due to risk of metabolic syndrome. ECG, LFTs, and BP are also monitored but metabolic is key.
Lithium monitoring in stable patients is 6-monthly (levels, renal function, thyroid). More frequent if unstable or dose changes. Annually is too infrequent.
Eating disorder requires urgent referral if BMI <16 (or <15 in adults) due to medical risk. BMI 14 is very low and high risk. Higher BMIs may need routine referral.
Self-harm requires risk assessment and appropriate referral (crisis team if high risk, routine if low). Never ignore, discourage discussion, or punish. Medication may be part of treatment.
Alcohol dependence first-line is brief intervention and referral to specialist services. Benzodiazepines for withdrawal should be supervised. Admission only if severe withdrawal.
Smoking in pregnancy - NRT (nicotine replacement therapy) is acceptable and safer than continued smoking. Cold turkey may be too difficult. E-cigarettes not recommended in pregnancy.

questions.stem: Safeguarding adults - who can raise concern:
questions.explanation: Safeguarding adults concerns can be raised by any professional who identifies risk. GP, social services, family, and police can all raise concerns. Not restricted to one group.

questions.stem: Mental Capacity Act - best interests decision considers:
questions.explanation: Best interests decisions under Mental Capacity Act must consider patient's past and present wishes, values, and beliefs. Not just clinician or family opinion. Cost and convenience are not primary factors.
Advance care planning should involve patient preferences and wishes while they have capacity. It should not be avoided, delayed, clinician-led only, or secret.
DNACPR should be discussed sensitively and early when appropriate, involving patient if possible. Not to be avoided, decided without patient, or only in hospital/when dying.
Complaints reflection should focus on learning and change to improve practice. Not just defence, blaming others, ignoring, or legal advice only.
Significant event analysis is for learning and improvement, not punishment. Documentation, reporting, and appraisal are secondary to the learning purpose.

questions.stem: Information governance - patient data should be:
questions.explanation: Patient data must be stored securely according to GDPR and data protection laws. Never shared freely, emailed unencrypted, made public, or treated as optional.

questions.stem: GMC Good Medical Practice core principle:
questions.explanation: GMC Good Medical Practice core principle is patient safety. Profit, speed, research, and autonomy are not the core principle, though they may be considerations.
Social media professional guidance requires maintaining boundaries between personal and professional. Not same as personal, free posting, ignoring patients, or assuming anonymity is safe.
AI acceptable use requires clinician oversight - AI can assist but not replace clinical decision-making. Never diagnose independently, replace decisions, enter public data, or use without disclosure.
AI documentation best practice requires clinician to review and edit all AI-generated content. Never copy blindly, avoid documentation, use without consent, or delete notes.

questions.stem: Partnership finance - partner income depends on:
questions.explanation: GP partner income depends on practice profit (after expenses). Not fixed salary, GMC, NHS England, or QOF alone - it's a share of practice profits.
GMS (General Medical Services) is the core NHS contract type for GP practices. PMS and APMS are alternatives. Private and local are not core contract types.

questions.stem: Workforce supervision - who supervises GP trainees:
questions.explanation: GP trainees are supervised by educational supervisor (usually a GP in the practice). Practice manager, reception, CQC, and GMC do not provide clinical supervision.

questions.stem: CQC domains - which is not a domain:
questions.explanation: CQC inspection domains are Safe, Effective, Caring, Responsive, and Well-led. Profitable is not a CQC domain - practices are not assessed on profitability.
keyPoints: CQC domains = Safe, Effective, Caring, Responsive, Well-led

questions.explanation: Communication failures are often the highest risk area in practice, leading to missed diagnoses, medication errors, and patient harm. Other areas are also important but communication is key.
GP indemnity covers civil claims (negligence, errors). It does not cover criminal acts, fraud, or misconduct. Not all actions are covered.

questions.stem: Coroner referral - which death requires referral:
questions.explanation: Sudden unexplained death requires coroner referral. Expected palliative death, old age, known cancer with expected death, and DNACPR do not require referral.
MCCD (Medical Certificate of Cause of Death) is completed by the treating doctor who attended the patient in their last illness. Not any doctor, coroner, registrar, or nurse.
Cremation now requires medical examiner review (since 2019). Old Form 4/5 system replaced. Not two doctors always or GP signature only.

questions.stem: Fitness to drive - who advises patient:
questions.explanation: GP advises patient about fitness to drive and may need to inform DVLA if patient doesn't. DVLA makes final decision. Employer, police, and GMC don't advise.
Professional boundaries allow small tokens of appreciation but large gifts should be declined. Never solicit gifts or ignore practice policy. Always consider context.
Whistleblowing guidance encourages speaking up appropriately through proper channels. Not silence, external media first, resignation, or social media.
GP role in health inequalities includes advocacy and improving access to care. Not ignoring, only clinical care, private work, or hospital referral only.
Effective leadership requires emotional intelligence - understanding and managing emotions, empathy, and relationship skills. Not just authority, speed, avoidance, or hierarchy.
Resilience is most effectively built through reflection and support networks. Working more, isolation, avoidance, and perfectionism reduce resilience.
Best exam mindset is to trust your preparation. Memorising everything, panicking, over-revising last night, and repeatedly changing answers reduce performance.
